description: Four musicians in an interior setting (piano, guitar, drum, cornet)

text: Beauford Delaney, a native of Tennessee, was one of many African-American artists who relocated to Paris where they felt their work could be judged on its merits, free from racial prejudices. The artist's style, highly-representational in his early career, became extremely abstracted in his later Paris years. Jazz Quartet, however, dates to Delaney's New York period when the artist was working in an expressionistic mode. Delaney's thick laying in of pigment also performs a synesthetic role in that the rhythms of jazz are evoked by the lively surface and rhythmic placement of forms. The heavily-textured surface also brings to mind the words of author Henry Miller, who recalled that the under-appreciated artist, though poor, was as lavish as a millionaire in his use of pigment.
title: Jazz Quartet
